description: The depolarizing channel is a fundamental noise model in quantum computing that describes the symmetric loss of quantum information. With probability p, the qubit undergoes a random Pauli error (X, Y, or Z with equal probability p/3 each), and with probability 1-p it remains unchanged.

This channel causes the quantum state to decay toward the maximally mixed state I/2, representing complete loss of both amplitude and phase information. It is often used as a worst-case or average-case noise model because it treats all types of errors symmetrically.

The depolarizing channel is particularly important because many QEM techniques are analyzed under depolarizing noise assumptions, and Pauli twirling can convert arbitrary noise into effective depolarizing noise.

quantum_channel.chi_matrix: Diagonal with entries \((1-p, p/3, p/3, p/3)\) in Pauli basis

physical_examples: Interaction with a high-temperature (infinite temperature) bath
Time-averaged effect of many small unknown errors
Effective noise after Pauli twirling arbitrary channels
Simplified model for benchmarking and analysis
qem_considerations: ZNE works well: noise scales predictably with circuit depth under depolarizing model
PEC can exactly cancel depolarizing noise with known error rate
Pauli twirling converts coherent errors to depolarizing-like noise
Clifford Data Regression training is effective when target noise is depolarizing
